title: Websites and Articles
text: In doing research on the topic of stop and frisk in NYC between the years 2003 and 2022 I came across these sites, which I found useful.

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
This is the second part of the 2023 NECOMMIT keynote given on Oct 21,2023.
Below you will find hints and code to mimic the data analysis we did with the sqf 2011 data on paper with arrows. Hints are labeled hints and the optional code is folded so it cannot be seen until clicked. We will work in a RScript file.

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
This is the second part of the 2023 NECOMMIT keynote given on Oct 21,2023.
Below you will find hints and code to mimic the data analysis we did with the sqf 2011 data on paper. Hints are labeled hints and the optional code is folded so it cannot be seen until clicked. We will work in a RScript file.

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
2 Setup

Go to posit cloud and set up an account.
Then click New RStudio Project  and give it a title.

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
3 Install and Load
First we need to install the tidyverse. This is where our functions come from. Do this in the console pane.

# You only need to run this once.
install.packages("tidyverse")

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
section: 6 Get the 2021 stop and frisk data
text:
6 Get the 2021 stop and frisk data

url_2021 <- "https://www.nyc.gov/assets/nypd/downloads/excel/analysis_and_planning/stop-question-frisk/sqf-2021.xlsx"
download.file(url_2021, "sqf-2021.xlsx")
sqf_2021 <- read_excel("sqf-2021.xlsx")

# The line below reads the total number of rows for the document. 
#. The total number of rows is the total number of stops. 

total_stops <- nrow(sqf_2021)

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
7 Now we can start.
I’d like to the recreate the data analysis we did on paper for 2011 but in R. There are suggested next steps below. You can always copy code to your RScript.

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
8 Recode your variables
This is probably the trickiest part:


recode to the race column
#Recode Suspect_Race_Description to group hispanic, you might think "Latino" is a better choice

sqf_2021$SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION<-
  recode(
    sqf_2021$SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION,
    "BLACK HISPANIC" =  "Hispanic",
    "WHITE HISPANIC"    = "Hispanic",
    "BLACK"=    "Black",
    "WHITE"=    "White",
    "MIDDLE EASTERN/SOUTHWEST ASIAN"=   "MESA",
    "ASIAN / PACIFIC ISLANDER"= "API",
    "AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKAN NATIVE"=   "AMAN",
    "no data"=  "no data",
    .default = NA_character_
  )




recode to the SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG column
# This will recode wether or not someone has been arrested. 1 is yes, 0 is no. 
#This will help us sum values later. 

sqf_2021$SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG<-
  recode(
    sqf_2021$SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG,
    "Y" =   1,
    "N" = 0
  )

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
section: 9 Take a look at the data with head(10)
text:
9 Take a look at the data with head(10)


Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  head(10)

# To see only the variable names you can  use 
sqf_2021 |>
  names()

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
10 Select the variables






hint





hint: select() the variables we’re interested SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION and SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE





Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
11 Rename the variables
rename() the variables to yell less (optional)


Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)|>
  rename("sex" = "SUSPECT_SEX",
         "race" = "SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION",
         "age" = "SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE",
         "arrested" = "SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG")

title: NECOMMIT cheat sheet
section: 10 Tally up all of the people by race.

title: NECOMMIT cheat sheet
NECOMMIT cheat sheet
NECOMMIT cheat sheet
Wrangling 2021 Data
section: 12 Tally up all of the stops by race.
text:
12 Tally up all of the stops by race.






hint





hint: group_by(race) and use summarize() to count all of the stops with n().





Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)|>
  rename("sex" = "SUSPECT_SEX",
         "race" = "SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION",
         "age" = "SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE",
         "arrested" = "SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG") |>
  group_by(race) |>
  summarise(stops_total=n())

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
section: 13 Find the percent stopped by race
text:
13 Find the percent stopped by race






hint





hint: Add another variable maybe percent_stopped that find the proportion of total stops to summarize().





Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)|>
  rename("sex" = "SUSPECT_SEX",
         "race" = "SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION",
         "age" = "SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE",
         "arrested" = "SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG") |>
  group_by(race) |>
  summarise(stops_by_race = n(),
            percent_stopped = n() / total_stops *100
  )

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
14 Find the percent arrested






hint





hint: Add a percent_arrested variable by adding to summarize().





Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)|>
  rename("sex" = "SUSPECT_SEX",
         "race" = "SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION",
         "age" = "SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE",
         "arrested" = "SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG") |>
  group_by(race) |>
  summarise(stops_by_race = n(),
            percent_stopped = n() / total_stops *100,
            percent_arrested = sum(arrested)/n() *100
  )

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
15 Order the percent_arrested column






hint





hint: arrange() the percent_arrested column so that they are in order.





Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)|>
  rename("sex" = "SUSPECT_SEX",
         "race" = "SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION",
         "age" = "SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE",
         "arrested" = "SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG") |>
  group_by(race) |>
  summarise(stops_by_race = n(),
            percent_stopped = n() / total_stops *100,
            percent_arrested = sum(arrested)/n() *100
  )|>
  arrange(percent_arrested)

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
Wrangling 2021 Data
section: 17 Extra 2: Add a bar that shows the percent stopped

title: NECOMMIT cheat sheet
section: 18 Extra 3: Add titles, axis labels, and a caption
text:
18 Extra 3: Add titles, axis labels, and a caption






hint





hint: Use the labs() function for this.





Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)|>
  rename("sex" = "SUSPECT_SEX",
         "race" = "SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION",
         "age" = "SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE",
         "arrested" = "SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG") |>
  group_by(race) |>
  summarise(stops_by_race = n(),
            percent_stopped = n() / total_stops *100,
            percent_arrested = sum(arrested)/n() *100
  )|>
  arrange(percent_arrested)|>
  
# Make the graph below. The information is being piped from the datafram above. 
  ggplot()+
  geom_col(aes(x=race,y=percent_arrested), alpha = 0.5,  fill="blue", width = 0.25, position = position_nudge(x=0.15))+
  geom_col(aes(x=race,y=percent_stopped),alpha=0.5,fill="red",width = 0.25, position = position_nudge(x=-0.15))+
  labs(
        y="", 
       title = "Percent Stopped and Percent Arrested", 
       caption = "The red bars show the percent of people stopped of the total. The blue bars show the percent arrested of each race.")+
  theme_minimal()

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
4 Open an RScript

File > New File > R Script
To run code in the R script you can highlight it and click 
All of the following code will be entered into your RScript

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
5 Load the libraries

library(tidyverse)
library(readxl)

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
section: 18 Extra 3: Add titles, axis labels, and a caption. Also add some text to the black bar for context.
text:
18 Extra 3: Add titles, axis labels, and a caption. Also add some text to the black bar for context.






hint





hint: Use the labs() function for this.





Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)|>
  rename("sex" = "SUSPECT_SEX",
         "race" = "SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION",
         "age" = "SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE",
         "arrested" = "SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG") |>
  group_by(race) |>
  summarise(stops_by_race = n(),
            percent_stopped = n() / total_stops *100,
            percent_arrested = sum(arrested)/n() *100
  )|>
  arrange(percent_arrested)|>
  
# Make the graph below. The information is being piped from the datafram above. 
  ggplot()+
  geom_col(aes(x=race,y=percent_arrested),   fill="blue", width = 0.25, position = position_nudge(x=0.15))+
  geom_col(aes(x=race,y=percent_stopped), fill="red",width = 0.25, position = position_nudge(x=-0.15))+
  labs(
        y="", 
       title = "Percent Stopped and Percent Arrested", 
       caption = "The red bars show the percent of people stopped of the total. The blue bars show the percent arrested of each race.")+
  theme_minimal()

title: NECOMMIT Fall '23
text:
Lindsay Porier of Smith College for pointing me to this data.
Many of the ideas for teaching Data Wrangling with paper cam from Chris Malone of Winona State University.

title: Websites and Articles
text:
Dan Nguyen’s Blog
Background, 2019

title: Stop and Frisk
text:
Introduction:

name: Nic Schwab
SDS department at Smith
Math department at Holyoke Community College
Develop a Data Science Program at HCC
email: nschwab@smith.edu



Why Data Science?

Math conference for teaching with Inquiry.
Math teachers will be the ones teaching data science.
Data Science lends itself to inquiry practices and active learning.



Why R?
Lots of resources available to learn R.
see Resources
Many alternatives

codap
NuMPI with python
google analytics



Stop, Question, Frisk

Started in the 1990s
New York City Police Practice

Police only need reasonable suspicion.

Many articles about the targeting of Black and Latino young men.
Studies have shown that this has led to mistrust in the police.



More about about me
I’m not Black.
I’m am Hispanic.
I’m White
I am not from New York City.


Race Exists
Let’s acknowledge that Race exists and plays a part in the way human being interact with each other.


Schedule:


Introduce you to the data.
Pose a question that I have about stop and frisk.
Give you Data Frames with data to answer the question one way.

You’ll order them with a partner.
You’ll make up puesdo code to explain data transformations.
I’ll give you the real code.

We’ll repeat the process of data wrangling in R.




Questions so far?


The Data
Here’s NYC’s website with the stop and frisk data.
Let’s consider 2011 data


Each column is a variable
and each row is a stop


Data Dictionaries exist for older data.
New Data variables are more clear.
The variable names are inconsistent across years.


SQF History in a graph

# Read in each csv file. This is a lot 

# With purr csv

file_paths_csv <- fs::dir_ls("../data/2003_2015_csv_files")

file_contents_csv<- file_paths_csv |>
  map(function (path){
    read_csv(path)
  })

# with purr excel

file_paths_xl <- fs::dir_ls("../data/2016_2022_xl_files")

file_contents_xl<- file_paths_xl |>
  map(function (path){
    read_excel(path)
  })

# https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=An1bUIg-nVM

#See the number of rows i.e stops in each year
pre_2016 <- sapply(file_contents_csv, nrow)
post_2016 <- sapply(file_contents_xl, nrow)


years <- c(2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020, 2021, 2022 )
stops_frisks <- c(160851, 313523, 398191, 506491, 472096, 540302, 581168,  601285, 685724, 532911,  191851, 45787, 22563, 12405, 11629,  11008,   13459,9544 , 8947,  15102)  

sqf <- data.frame(years,stops_frisks)



sqf |> 
  ggplot(aes(years,stops_frisks)) +
  
  geom_rect(aes(xmin=2002,xmax=2014,ymin=0,ymax=Inf),fill="#003585",alpha=0.01)+
  geom_rect(aes(xmin=2014,xmax=2021,ymin=0,ymax=Inf),fill="#FFFFFF",alpha=0.01)+
  geom_rect(aes(xmin=2021,xmax=2022,ymin=0,ymax=Inf),fill="#FF6600",alpha=0.01)+
  geom_line()+
  xlab("Year")+
  ylab("Citizens Stopped ('000s)")+
  labs(title="")+
  theme_minimal()+
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = c(0,350000,700000), labels = c("0","350","700"))+
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(2003,2013,2022))+
  geom_text(label="Bloomberg", x = 2004.5, y = 40000, color="gray35" ) +
  geom_text(label="de Blasio", x = 2016, y = 40000, color="gray35" ) +
  geom_text(label="Adams", x = 2022, y = 40000, color="gray35" ) +
  geom_text(label=". NYCLU \n suit", x = 2013, y = 650000, color="gray35" ) +
  geom_vline(xintercept=2012, linetype = 3 )






Questions



Which racial groups were most likely to be stopped by police officers 2011?
What percent of the stops resulted in an arrest in 2011?
How do the answers to these questions change in 2021?





Here are your data frames

Little envelopes Data 2011


Put the Data Frames in Order.
Be sure you can explain the process from one DF to another.


Little envelopes Functions


After the frames are in Order put the code arrows between each frame.

title: Post Envelope digestion
text:
Have we answered our question?


Wrangling Functions
All functions come the dplyr which is loaded with the tidyverse. There are many more functions. See the cheat sheet



function
does




select()
selects columns from df


group_by()
groups levels of a column for later functions


summarise()
preforms summary operations.


rename()
renames the levels of a column.





Graphing Functions
ggplot2 handles graphing, it is loaded with the tidyverse. cheatsheet



function
does




ggplot()
setsup a plot, needs df and aes()


geom_col()
makes column graphs based on aes(x,y)


labs()
adds labels to graphs.


theme_minimal()
A theme to clean things up





Operators








symbol
name
operation




<-
arrow operator
saves an object to the variable on the left


|>
pipe
moves an object into the first argument of a function.


$
dollar sign operator
Accesses one variable in a dataset.

title: Nic Schwab
text:
Nicholas Schwab is a visiting lecturer in Statistical and Data Sciences. He is a tenured professor at Holyoke Community College. When not teaching data science, he enjoys rock climbing, running, and reading children’s books to his kids.

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
text:
7 Now we can start
I’d like to the recreate the data analysis we did on paper for 2011 but in R. There are suggested next steps below. You can always copy code to your RScript file.

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
section: 16 Make a bar graph of percent stopped
text:
16 Make a bar graph of percent stopped






hint





hint: pipe |> the data_frame above into ggplot() choose x= race, y= percent_arrested for your aesthetics. The pipe that into geom_col(). Add +theme_minimal() to make it clean.





Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)|>
  rename("sex" = "SUSPECT_SEX",
         "race" = "SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION",
         "age" = "SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE",
         "arrested" = "SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG") |>
  group_by(race) |>
  summarise(stops_by_race = n(),
            percent_stopped = n() / total_stops *100,
            percent_arrested = sum(arrested)/n() *100
  )|>
  arrange(percent_arrested)|>
  
# Make the graph below. The information is being piped from the datafram above. 
  ggplot(aes(x=race,y=percent_stopped)) +
  geom_col()+
  theme_minimal()

title: Wrangling 2021 Data
section: 17 Extra 2: Add titles, axis labels and color the graph red.
text:
17 Extra 2: Add titles, axis labels and color the graph red.






hint





hint: Use the labs() function for this.





Show the code
sqf_2021 |>
  select(SUSPECT_SEX, SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION, SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE, SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG)|>
  rename("sex" = "SUSPECT_SEX",
         "race" = "SUSPECT_RACE_DESCRIPTION",
         "age" = "SUSPECT_REPORTED_AGE",
         "arrested" = "SUSPECT_ARRESTED_FLAG") |>
  group_by(race) |>
  summarise(stops_by_race = n(),
            percent_stopped = n() / total_stops *100,
            percent_arrested = sum(arrested)/n() *100
  )|>
  arrange(percent_arrested)|>
  
# Make the graph below. The information is being piped from the datafram above. 
  ggplot()+
  geom_col(aes(x=race,y=percent_stopped), fill="red",)+
  labs(
        y="Percent", 
       title = "People stopped by race in 2021", 
  )+
  theme_minimal()
